comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From the Irish Independent, Saturday, 7 November 1914:
The Viceroy in Waterford Addresses and Presentations The Lord Lieutenant and Lady Aberdeen visited Waterford yesterday for the purpose of presenting the Fagan Shield (the gift of Sir John Fagan) to the St. Dominick Industrial School, conducted by the Good Shepherd Nuns. The competition in regard to the Shield is triennial, for housewifery and domestic science, and extends to all Irish Industrial Schools. Their Excellencies, who were accompanied by Sir Wm. Thompson, were met at the railway station by the Mayor (Mr. R. Power), the High Sheriff (Mr. M. McDonald), and members of the Corporation, and an address was presented welcoming the Lord Lieutenant on behalf of the citizens. In reply, Lord Aberdeen said the welcome extended to them was "full of significance and most gratifying." He acknowledged the sympathy extended towards the Belgian refugees and towards the wounded from the scene of war. ... At the City Hall, an address from the Corporation to Lady Aberdeen was read ... On arrival at the Good Shepherd Convent their Excellencies were presented with an illuminated address, read by Nancy Lidwell ... The Right Rev. Dr. Sheehan joined in the welcome, and said the children said the joy of winning the shield was added to by the joy of receiving it from the hands of Lady Aberdeen ... The Irish, said his Lordship, were not an ungrateful people, and they followed with interest the careers of those who had been good in their land ... Col. Flinn, Chief Inspector of Industrial Schools, having alluded to the manner in which the children of St. Dominick's had won the shield, the trophy was duly handed by her Excellency to Katie Wynne and Eily Traynor. The pupils then gave an entertainment, after which the industrial work of the pupils was inspected...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16693700@N03] Was Edmond de la Poer an official for Waterford only?? It looks as if we're talking about John Hamilton-Gordon, 1st Marquess of Aberdeen and Temair, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (for the second time) from December 1905-February 1916.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/]Thanks for posting this Carol, much better in high res! Yes that is John Harrison holding the mace, sadly a couple of years after this photo was taken he lost his son in the war. From The Waterford News - 22th of September 1916. "THE ROLL OF HONOUR. Several letters have been received in Waterford from soldiers at the front annoucing the death of Sergeant John Harrison, Leinster Regiment, son of Sergeant-at-Mace Harrison. Sergeant Harrison was quite a young man. He was in the South Irish Horse for some years, and during the special recruiting campaign in Waterford in March, 1915, he joined the cadet corps of the Leinster Regiment. He has been for some time at the front, and, although his death is not officially announced, there appears to be little doubt but that he has been killed, as the writer of one of the letters referred to stated that poor Jack Harrison was killed alongside of him, and that he only lived a short time after being struck. Amongst all who knew John Harrison he was very popular, and his death will be generally regretted. Deep sympathy will also be felt with his widow, father mother and other relatives in their bereavement." www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/history-heritage/page...

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Sgt. John Harrison, aged 25, was killed at the Somme on the 9th of September 1916. Son of John and Margaret Harrison, of 24, Ballybricken, Waterford. He has no known grave, (i.e. his body was never found), but is commemorated on the Thiepval Memorial. The Thiepval Memorial, the Memorial to the Missing of the Somme, bears the names of more than 72,000 officers and men of the United Kingdom and South African forces who died in the Somme sector before 20 March 1918 and have no known grave. Over 90% of those commemorated died between July and November 1916.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Beautiful photograph Carol and its great to have so many in it identified.  I'm surprised that someone as astute as the Bwana would have thought that anybody other than a Mayor would sit in the Mayors seat and wear the chain in the council chamber?  In terms of protocol in those circumstances the local Mayor takes precedence and as the holder of the local office would wear the regalia and speak from the seat.
